verbs and introduction phrasal verbs
aren't easy to figure out are they do
you know what I have here grammar books
I've been looking through books and
websites to make sure that I have a
solid understanding of phrasal verbs but
do you know what I'm finding out there's
a lot of different information about
phrasal verbs that makes it kind of
confusing but it's my goal to sort
everything out and offer you a clear
explanation of phrasal verbs I'd like to
help you learn the answers to these
three questions
what are phrasal verbs when do we use
them how do we use them let's start with
our first question
what are phrasal verbs phrasal verbs are
also called
two-part verbs three-part verbs and
multi-word verbs I like the term phrasal
verb we're talking about a verb and one
or two other short words together as a
phrase they have a special meaning these
one or two other short words can be
called particles when these particles
come together with the verb a new
definition is made the particles change
the original definition this is
different from just a verb and a
preposition or a verb and an adverb
prepositions and adverbs add information
but they don't change the original
definition of the verb particles do so
far you've heard me use four phrasal
verbs how did the particles change the
original definitions of the verbs figure
out means understand after much thought
look through means search for something
find out means discover or learn
information sort out means organize
something messy or complicated
learning the definitions of phrasal
verbs is probably the biggest challenge
for students after all there are
hundreds of phrasal verbs used in
English the definitions of some phrasal
verbs are rather easy to understand
because they're more literal that means
their meanings are still close to the
original definition of the verb for
example look through look means to see
with your eyes to look through a book
means you're searching through the book
you're using your eyes and you're going
from one end of the book to the other
searching for information figure out is
a phrasal verb that's more idiomatic the
meaning is not quite clear by just
looking at the two parts figure out to
figure out a mouth problem means you
think about it a lot and then you
finally understand it I'd like to
emphasize the importance of particles
compare these two statements the boy
looked through the keyhole the lawyer
looked through the files I would argue
that we have only one example of a
phrasal verb where is it in the second
statement in the first sentence through
the keyhole is additional information we
just learn more information about where
the boy is looking where he is directing
his eyes to see through does not change
the definition of look but in the second
sentence we add the particle through to
look and we get a new definition search
the lawyer looked through the files
the lawyer searched the files now
consider the short list of verb phrases
agree on an issue care about someone
dream of a better life in my opinion
these are not examples of phrasal verbs
because on a belt and of are not
changing or extending the definitions of
the verbs that they follow
exercise one identify the phrasal verb
in each pair of statements example watch
and listen
which statement has a phrasal verb a
Jennifer is sitting on the couch and
reading a magazine B Jennifer likes to

chance which statement had a phrasal
verb be
sit back means to get comfortable to
rest in a comfortable position 1 which

is thinking about what she can cook for
dinner
be jennifer is thinking over what she
wrote in her complaint letter was it
ready to send which statement had a
phrasal verb be think / thank / means
carefully consider especially before
making a decision to which statement has
a phrasal verb thanks for calling by a
Jennifer said goodbye and hung up B
pictures and photographs hang on
Jennifer's walls which statement had a
phrasal verb a hang up hang up means to
end a phone call 3 which statement has a
phrasal verb a Jennifer didn't get
around to vacuuming until after 2:00 in
the afternoon B Jennifer was happy she
got her new coat for only $10 which
statement had a phrasal verb a to get
around to something or get around to
doing something means you finally do it
after a lot of delay let's move on to
our second question when do we use
phrasal verbs
phrasal verbs are common in everyday
English they are often less appropriate
for formal speech than their one-word
equivalents for example come up with is
a phrasal verb that means invent create
similarly put together could be replaced
with the single verb assemble or prepare
so depending on how formal a situation
is I'll decide whether or not to use
phrasal verbs if asked informally to
talk about my work I would explain that
I really enjoy coming up with ideas and
putting together lessons for you my
viewers but in a more formal situation
if asked the same question I would use
different wording let me show you some
of the changes I would make I thoroughly
enjoy both the challenge of generating
ideas and the experience of preparing
lessons for my viewers do you feel how
this statement is more formal I think
that idioms are less common in formal
English so because there are so many
idiomatic phrasal verbs they're more
common in everyday English more informal
situations exercise to consider the
statement as a whole which verb is more
appropriate example the newspaper
reported that the businessman was
extremely disappointed to find out or to
discover one of his own employees had
committed a major crime in this
statement both verbs could work neither
one is incorrect they both have the same
meaning but overall the language of the
statement is more formal I'd argue that
discover is a better choice I think
you'll understand even better if we
compare that first statement to this
second one this is more informal this is
a spoken statement I read in the
newspaper that the businessman was
really upset to find out an employee of
his was guilty of a serious crime again
both verbs could work but because it's
more informal find out is a better
choice
one read the statement and choose which
verb you think is more appropriate think
over is not incorrect but for this more
formal statement I would choose consider
we are greatly interested in your
proposal but we will require some time
to consider all our options to
searches is not incorrect but for this
informal statement I would choose looks
through it drives me crazy when my
sister looks through my things without
asking I have to tell her to stay on her
side of the room three figure out is not
incorrect but I would choose determine
her doctors failed to determine the
cause of the illness however they were
able to reduce the patient suffering the
